title: Preservice Training
text:
Would you rather?



have class for 12 hours on one day a week
have breakfast for every meal of the day
have class at 8am every day
spend your day reading





have class for 2hrs a day 6 days a week
not drink any caffeine ever again
have class at 8pm every day
spend your day hiking



How would you spend your day, if you could choose anything?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Reflection
What are ice-breakers for?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Reflection
Why do we have to learn to talk to people we don’t know?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Discuss in small groups
Think about the answer individually first, then share with your group:

What does it mean to be a good TA?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Discuss in small groups
From the answers shared (Q: What does it mean to be a good TA?), did your group think of all these three categories:

What does it mean to be a good TA to you?
What does it mean to be a good TA to students?
What does it mean to be a good TA to the instructor you are working for?

Using the color post-its, write at least two answers in each category.

title: Preservice Training
text:
Reflection

Why allow participants to think individually first?
Why have them share in small groups second?
Why have groups share with everyone as the last step?

title: Preservice Training
section: What skills are needed for TAing?
text:
What skills are needed for TAing?

Technical knowledge
Pedagogical practice and experience
Interpersonal communication

Which of these are you most confident with?
Which of these you think you should develop further?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Scenarios
Come up with 3 reasonable reactions to your group’s scenario.
The goal is not to come up with “the right response”, but to generate possible reactions to the given scenarios that are reasonable and respectful of all parties involved.
“reasonable reaction” means that it would:

support the student(s) involved AND
be something you would be comfortable doing

title: Preservice Training
text:
Scenarios
Come up with 3 reasonable reactions to your group’s scenario.

Select your group number:   1 2 3 4 


Your group’s scenario is:

title: Preservice Training
text:
Scenarios
What phrases would you be comfortable telling the student in the scenario?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Student Experiences & Backgrounds
What behaviors might make some students appear to be better learners when you are interacting with them as a TA?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Student Experiences & Backgrounds
Which of these behaviors do you tend to exhibit in office hours and lecture?
How many of these behaviors are learned from culture (background/experience/personality)?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Learner Profiles
Think of 3 specific kinds of support that these student might benefit from.
The goal here is for you to consider supports that are not directly related to course content (e.g., language support, computer support) students may need without generalizing any one group.

Read their profile
This student is in your office hours. What sorts of problems might they be asking about?

title: Preservice Training
text:
X
X is a first year student from Oregon. They took computer science during high school and passed the AP test, which was in Java. They are currently taking CSC 110, an introductory course in python. They were not top of their class, but they were in the top 20% at their high school. They frequently turn in homework that uses concepts not covered during lecture.

title: Preservice Training
text:
Y
Y is a first-year, international student. They read English very well but sometimes struggle to understand when their teachers speak quickly or mumble. The time difference makes it difficult to talk to their family back home. Y did not attend an international high school, nor was their high school a bilingual English one. They are taking CS 120 currently, and the first exam is approaching. Y has no family connections nearby.

The goal is not to come up with “the right response”, but to generate possible reactions to the given scenarios that are reasonable and respectful of all parties involved.
“reasonable reaction” means that it would:

support the student(s) involved AND
be something you would be comfortable doing

title: CS UGTA Training
text:
Training dates:

Preservice (meaning before the semester starts):

January 8 (Monday), 1pm to 3pm in GS 228
January 9 (Tuesday), 1pm to 3pm in GS 228

Inservice (meaning after you’ve had some TA experience)

January 20 (Saturday), 1pm to 3pm in GS 228


If you have any questions please contact Adriana Picoral at adrianaps@arizona.edu

title: About
text:
The training materials in this website have been put together based the following:
Felix Muzny and Michael D. Shah. 2023. Teaching Assistant Training: An Adjustable Curriculum for Computing Disciplines. In Proceedings of the 54th ACM Technical Symposium on Computing Science Education V. 1 (SIGCSE 2023), March 15–18, 2023, Toronto, ON, Canada. ACM, New York, NY, USA, 7 pages. https://doi.org/10.1145/3545945.3569866

title: Preservice Training
text:
Reviewing of previous day
Discuss in your groups:

What are ice-breakers good for?
What are the three types of skills needed for teaching/TAing?
What are some questions/phrases you can use to help students during in-class activities and office hours?

title: Preservice Training
text:

What are ice-breakers good for?

What are some questions/phrases you can use to help students during in-class activities and office hours?

title: Preservice Training
text:
Questions
We will replicate the experience of dealing with unfamiliar code (like trying to understand what students wrote).
Write down as many questions as you can about the following code snippet.

mean_ci <- function(x, conf = 0.95) {
  se <- sd(x) / sqrt(length(x))
  alpha <- 1 - conf
  mean(x) + se * qnorm(c(alpha / 2, 1 - alpha / 2))
}

x <- runif(100)
mean_ci(x)

[1] 0.4920997 0.6068181

title: Preservice Training
text:
Open vs. Close questions
For each question your group wrote, categorize it as “open” or “closed”.
An “open” question is a question that leads to further discussion.
A “closed” question is one that has a single, fixed answer.

title: Preservice Training
text:
Asking questions
Come up with questions that:

helps you understand the student code
generates discussion
helps the student understand their code

title: Preservice Training
text:
Survey
Please fill our survey

title: Inservice Training
text:
Group Discussion

What is one thing that you have done well in your job as a TA so far?
When did you have to think hard in your job as a TA?
What have you learned so far working as a TA?
What is one thing you’d like to work on over the remainder of the term?

title: Inservice Training
text:
Teaching Difficult Concepts
Individually (write your answer down):
What has been the most difficult topic that students have encountered so far?
OR
What do you think will be the most difficult topic presented in their course?

title: Inservice Training
text:
Group Discussion
Go around and find people with a similar concept than yours (it might not overlap perfectly)
Once you’ve found your group:

Choose which concept you will work on
Develop a short lesson on the topic – the lesson should include one small example problem

title: Inservice Training
text:
Share + Feedback
Share your mini-lesson and example with the large group
Feedback, write down (email me your feedback at adrianaps@arizona.edu):

one thing that the group did well
one thing that they could improve

title: Inservice Training
text:
Group Discussion

What is one difficult/challenging scenario that you have encountered in your job as a TA so far?
How do you think that the stereotypes that a student may have heard about computer science/programming might impact how they approach the materials in the classroom?
In your job as a TA, have you seen these stereotypes/myths play out? How? Where?

title: Inservice Training
text:
Asking Questions
What questions can you ask the student to help them understand what the problem is with their code?

def max_consec_sum(numbers, n):
  sum = 0
  new_sum = 0
  for i in range(len(numbers)):
    if i < n:
      sum += numbers[i]
    elif i+n < len(numbers):
      new_sum = sum - numbers[i-1] + numbers[i+n]
    if new_sum > sum:
      sum = new_sum
  return sum

print( max_consec_sum([10,2,-3,4,3],4) ) # 13
print( max_consec_sum([10,2,-3,4,3],1) ) # 10
print( max_consec_sum([10,2,-3,4,3],5)) # 16

13
18
16

title: Inservice Training
text:
Scenario
A student comes to your office hours with a solution to the following problem:
write a function that returns the maximum sum of n consecutive numbers in a list
The student says that their solution works only sometimes.
